galvanize.meaning: verb: to excite or inspire (someone) to action
galvanize.sentence: At mile 23 of his first marathon, Kyle had all but given up, until he noticed his friends and family holding a banner that read, “Go Kyle”; galvanized, he broke into a gallop, finishing the last three miles in less than 20 minutes.

equivocal.sentence: The findings of the study were equivocal—the two researchers had different opinions on what the results signified.

harangue.meaning: noun: a long pompous speech; a tirade
harangue.sentence: Dinner at Billy's was more a punishment than a reward, since anyone who sat at the dinner table would have to listen to Billy's father's interminable harangues against the government.

impertinent.meaning: adjective: being disrespectful; improperly forward or bold
impertinent.sentence: Dexter, distraught over losing his pet dachshund, Madeline, found the police officer’s questions impertinent—after all, he thought, did she have to pry into such details as to what Madeline’s favorite snack was?

egregious.meaning: adjective: standing out in a negative way; shockingly bad
egregious.sentence: The dictator’s abuse of human rights was so egregious that many world leaders demanded that he be tried in an international court for genocide.

venality.meaning: noun: the condition of being susceptible to bribes or corruption
venality.sentence: Even some of the most sacred sporting events are not immune to venality, as many of the officials have received substantial bribes to make biased calls.

parsimonious.sentence: Katie is so parsimonious that she only buys a pair of socks if all of her other socks have holes in them.

commensurate.meaning: adjective: to be in proportion or corresponding in degree or amount
commensurate.sentence: The convicted felon’s life sentence was commensurate with the heinousness of his crime.

parochial.meaning: adjective: narrowly restricted in scope or outlook
parochial.sentence: Jasmine was sad to admit it, but her fledgling relationship with Jacob did not work out because his culinary tastes were simply too parochial; "After all," she quipped on her blog, "he considered Chef Boyardee ethnic food."

upbraid.sentence: Bob took a risk walking into the "Students Barbershop"—in the end he had to upbraid the apparently drunk barber for giving him an uneven bowl cut.

involved.meaning: adjective: complicated, and difficult to comprehend
involved.sentence: The physics lecture became so involved that the undergraduate’s eyes glazed over.

frugal.meaning: adjective: not spending much money (but spending wisely)
frugal.sentence: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.

castigate.sentence: Drill sergeants are known to castigate new recruits so mercilessly that the latter often break down during their first week in training.

demur.meaning: verb: to object or show reluctance
demur.sentence: Wallace disliked the cold, so he demurred when his friends suggested they go skiing in the Alps.

ingenuous.meaning: adjective: to be naïve and innocent
ingenuous.sentence: Two-years in Manhattan had changed Jenna from an ingenuous girl from the suburbs to a jaded urbanite, unlikely to fall for any ruse, regardless of how elaborate.

prevaricate.meaning: verb: to speak in an evasive way
prevaricate.sentence: The cynic quipped, “There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to prevaricate”.

vindicate.meaning: verb: to clear of accusation, blame, suspicion, or doubt with supporting arguments or proof
vindicate.sentence: Even seven Tour de France wins cannot vindicate Lance Armstrong in the eyes of the public--that the athlete used performance enhancing drugs invalidates all those wins.

amenable.sentence: Even though she did not like the outdoors, Shirley was generally amenable and so her brother was able to persuade her to go camping.

ambivalent.meaning: adjective: mixed or conflicting emotions about something
ambivalent.sentence: Sam was ambivalent about studying for the exam because doing so ate up a lot of his time, yet he was able to improve his analytical skills.

venerate.sentence: The professor, despite his sleep-inducing lectures, was venerated amongst his colleagues, publishing more papers yearly than all of his peers combined.

intimate.sentence: At first Manfred’s teachers intimated to his parents that he was not suited to skip a grade; when his parents protested, teachers explicitly told them that, notwithstanding the boy’s precocity, he was simply too immature to jump to the 6th grade.

artful.sentence: Picasso is generally considered the most artful member of the Cubist movement.

mercurial.meaning: adjective: (of a person) prone to unexpected and unpredictable changes in mood
mercurial.sentence: The fact that Ella’s moods were as mercurial as the weather was problematic for her relationships—it didn’t help that she lived in Chicago.

disinterested.sentence: The potential juror knew the defendant, and therefore could not serve on the jury, which must consist only of disinterested members.

calumny.meaning: noun: making of a false statement meant to injure a person’s reputation
calumny.sentence: With the presidential primaries well under way, the air is thick with calumny, and the mud already waist-high.

acrimony.sentence: The acrimony between the president and vice-president sent a clear signal to voters: the health of the current administration was imperiled.

Magoosh.meaning: noun: An online GRE prep product used by tens of thousands of students worldwide. Learn more at gre.magoosh.com.
Magoosh.sentence: After using Magoosh, Tom improved his GRE score by 8 points and was then admitted into UC Berkeley.

undermine.meaning: verb: to weaken (usually paired with an abstract term)
undermine.sentence: The student undermined the teacher’s authority by questioning the teacher’s judgment on numerous occasions.

iconoclast.meaning: noun: somebody who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions
iconoclast.sentence: Lady Gaga, in challenging what it means to be clothed, is an iconoclast for wearing a "meat dress" to a prominent awards show.

wanting.sentence: She did not think her vocabulary was wanting, yet there were so many words that inevitably she found a few she didn't know.

laconic.meaning: adjective: (describes a person, speech, or style of writing) using very few words
laconic.sentence: While Martha always swooned over the hunky, laconic types in romantic comedies, her boyfriends inevitably were very talkative—and not very hunky.

amorphous.sentence: His study plan for the GRE was at best amorphous; he would do questions from random pages in any one of seven test prep books.

innocuous.meaning: adjective: harmless and doesn’t produce any ill effects
innocuous.sentence: Everyone found Nancy’s banter innocuous—except for Mike, who felt like she was intentionally picking on him.

enervate.sentence: John preferred to avoid equatorial countries; the intense sun would always leave him enervated after he’d spent the day sightseeing.

extant.meaning: adjective: still in existence (usually refers to documents).
extant.sentence: Despite many bookstores closing, experts predict that some form of book dealing will still be extant generations from now.

qualify.meaning: verb: to make less severe; to limit (a statement)
qualify.sentence: Chris qualified his love for San Francisco, adding he didn't like the weather there as much as he liked the weather in Los Angeles.

restive.sentence: The crowd grew restive as the comedian’s opening jokes fell flat.

betray.meaning: verb: to reveal or make known something, usually unintentionally
betray.sentence: With the gold medal at stake, the gymnast awaited his turn, his quivering lip betraying his intense emotions.

anomalous.sentence: According to those who do not believe in climate change, the extreme weather over the last five years is simply anomalous—daily temperatures should return to their old averages, they believe.

censure.sentence: After being caught in bed with a mistress, the mayor was quickly censured by the city council.

profligate.meaning: adjective: spending resources recklessly or wastefully
profligate.sentence: The composer Wagner, while living on a limited salary, was so profligate as to line all the walls of his apartment with pure silk.

chastise.sentence: Though chastised for eating the snacks for the party, Lawrence shrugged off his mother’s harsh words, and continued to plow through jars of cookies and boxes of donuts.

veracious.sentence: While we elect our leaders in the hope that every word they speak  will be veracious, history has shown that such a hope is naive.

aberration.meaning: noun: a deviation from what is normal or expected
aberration.sentence: Aberrations in climate have become the norm: rarely a week goes by without some meteorological phenomenon making headlines.

apathetic.meaning: adjective: marked by a lack of interest
apathetic.sentence: Mr. Thompson was so talented at teaching math that even normally apathetic students took interest.

audacious.meaning: adjective: willing to be bold in social situations or to take risks
audacious.sentence: As all of the other campers cowered in their tents, Bill, armed only with a flashlight, audaciously tracked down the bear that had raided their food.

impudent.sentence: In an impudent move, the defendant spoke out of order to say terribly insulting things to the judge.

perfidy.meaning: noun: an act of deliberate betrayal; a breach of a trust
perfidy.sentence: Sure, he was the best salesman in the company; but Michael had abused the trust of the firm, sharing product secrets with a competitor, and for such perfidy he was terminated.

recondite.meaning: adjective: difficult to penetrate; incomprehensible to one of ordinary understanding or knowledge
recondite.sentence: I found Ulysses recondite and never finished the book, waiting instead to read it with someone else so we could penetrate its meaning together.

predilection.sentence: Monte had a predilection for the fine things in life: Cuban cigars, 200 dollar bottles of wine, and trips to the French Riviera.

platitude.meaning: noun: a trite or obvious remark
platitude.sentence: The professor argued that many statements regarded as wise in previous times, such as the Golden Rule, are now regarded as mere platitudes.

entrenched.sentence: By the time we reach 60-years old, most of our habits are so entrenched that it is difficult for us to change.

prescience.meaning: noun: the power to foresee the future
prescience.sentence: Baxter's warnings about investing in technology stocks seemed like an act of prescience after the whole market declined significantly.

frivolous.meaning: adjective: not serious in content or attitude or behavior
frivolous.sentence: Compared to Juliet's passionate concern for human rights, Jake's non-stop concern about football seems somewhat frivolous.

diffident.meaning: adjective: showing modest reserve; lacking self-confidence
diffident.sentence: As a young girl she was diffident and reserved, but now as an adult, she is confident and assertive.

gossamer.meaning: adjective: characterized by unusual lightness and delicacy
gossamer.sentence: The gossamer wings of a butterfly, which allow it to fly, are also a curse, so delicate that they are often damaged.

gainsay.meaning: verb: deny or contradict; speak against or oppose
gainsay.sentence: I can't gainsay a single piece of evidence James has presented, but I still don't trust his conclusion.

decorous.meaning: adjective: characterized by good taste in manners and conduct
decorous.sentence: Sally's parties are decorous affairs, and instead of the usual beer and music, there is tea and intellectual conversation.

inexorable.meaning: adjective: impossible to stop or prevent
inexorable.sentence: The rise of the computer was an inexorable shift in technology and culture.

bucolic.meaning: adjective: relating to the pleasant aspects of the country
bucolic.sentence: The noble families of England once owned vast expanses of beautiful, bucolic land.

incisive.meaning: adjective: having or demonstrating ability to recognize or draw fine distinctions
incisive.sentence: The lawyer had an incisive mind, able in a flash to dissect a hopelessly tangled issue and isolate the essential laws at play.

exacerbate.sentence: Her sleeplessness exacerbated her cold--when she woke up the next day, her sinuses were completely blocked.

gall.meaning: noun: the trait of being rude and impertinent
gall.sentence: The speeding car had the gall to switch five lanes at once, run through a red light, and then cut off a police car before finally coming to a stop in front of a sea of flashing red lights.

didactic.sentence: Tolstoy's The Death of Ivan Ilyich is a didactic novel, instructing the reader on how to live a good life.

culpability.sentence: Since John had left his banana peel at the top of the stairwell, he accepted culpability for Martha's broken leg.

aesthete.meaning: noun: one who professes great sensitivity to the beauty of art and nature
aesthete.sentence: A true aesthete, Marty would spend hours at the Guggenheim Museum, staring at the same Picasso.

torpor.meaning: noun: inactivity resulting from lethargy and lack of vigor or energy
torpor.sentence: After work, I was expecting my colleagues to be enthusiastic about the outing, but I found them in a state of complete torpor.

mitigate.meaning: verb: make less severe or harsh
mitigate.sentence: I can only spend so much time mitigating your disagreements with your wife, and at certain point, you need to do it on your own.

banal.meaning: adjective: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
banal.sentence: The professor used such banal expression that many students in the class either fell asleep from boredom or stayed awake to complete his sentences and humor friends.

volubility.meaning: noun: the quality of talking or writing easily and continuously
volubility.sentence: The professor's volubility knows no bounds; he could talk through a hurricane and elaborate a point from one St. Patrick's Day to the next.

aesthetic.meaning: adjective: concerned with the appreciation of beauty
aesthetic.sentence: The director, not known for his aesthetic sensibilities, decided not to use costumes at all, and put on the play in everyday clothing.

fortuitous.meaning: adjective: occurring by happy chance; having no cause or apparent cause
fortuitous.sentence: Missing my train turned out to be quite fortuitous since I ran into a childhood friend on the next train and we were able to reconnect after so many years.

reticent.meaning: adjective: disinclined to talk, not revealing one's thoughts
reticent.sentence: When asked about her father, Helen lost her outward enthusiasm and became rather reticent.

vociferous.meaning: adjective: conspicuously and offensively loud; given to vehement outcry
vociferous.sentence: In giving Marcia a particular vociferous response, Paul caused people at every other table in the restaurant to turn around and look at them angrily.

preclude.meaning: verb: keep from happening or arising; make impossible
preclude.sentence: The manager specified that all other gates be locked, to preclude the possibility of persons without tickets entering the arena undetected.

engender.sentence: The restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles were so severe that they engendered deep hatred and resentment in the German people.

germane.sentence: The professor wanted to tell the jury in detail about his new book, but the lawyer said it wasn't germane to the charges in the cases.

cryptic.meaning: adjective: mysterious or vague, usually intentionally
cryptic.sentence: Since Sarah did not want her husband to guess the Christmas present she had bought him, she only answered cryptically when he would ask her questions about it.

dogmatic.meaning: adjective: highly opinionated, not accepting that one's own beliefs may not be correct
dogmatic.sentence: Bryan is dogmatic in his belief that the earth is flat, claiming that all pictures of a spherical earth are computer generated.

deferential.sentence: If you ever have the chance to meet the president, stand up straight and be deferential.

culminate.meaning: verb: reach the highest or most decisive point
culminate.sentence: Beethoven's musical genius culminated in the 9th Symphony, which many consider his greatest work.

querulous.sentence: The querulous old woman was beginning to wear down even the happier members of the staff with her ceaseless complaining.

obscure.sentence: On the Smith's drive through the Grand Canyon, Mr. Smith's big head obscured much of Mrs. Robinson's view, so that she only saw momentary patches of red rock.

glut.sentence: The Internet offers such a glut of news related stories that many find it difficult to know which story to read first.

lambast.sentence: Showing no patience, the manager utterly lambasted the sales team that lost the big account.

eschew.meaning: verb: avoid and stay away from deliberately; stay clear of
eschew.sentence: Politicians are the masters of eschewing morals; academics are the masters of eschewing clarity.

mawkish.meaning: adjective: overly sentimental to the point that it is disgusting
mawkish.sentence: The film was incredibly mawkish, introducing highly likeable characters only to have them succumb to a devastating illness by the end of the movie.

rustic.meaning: adjective: characteristic of rural life; awkwardly simple and provincial
rustic.sentence: The vacation cabin had no electricity and no indoor plumbing, but despite these inconveniences, Nigel adored its rustic charm.

chortle.meaning: verb: to chuckle, laugh merrily, often in a breathy, muffled way
chortle.sentence: Walking into the cafe, I could hear happy, chortling people and smell the rich aroma of roasted coffee beans.

meanings.meaning: adjective: serving no useful purpose
meanings.sentence: How can we hope to stay open if we don't eliminate all superfluous spending, like catered meetings and free acupuncture Tuesday?

meanings.meaning: adjective: more than is needed, desired, or required
meanings.sentence: The third paragraph in your essay is superfluous and can be deleted.

lionize.meaning: verb: assign great social importance to
lionize.sentence: Students in the U.S. learn to lionize Jefferson, Franklin, and Washington because they are the founding fathers of the nation.

poignant.sentence: After the Montagues and Capulets discover the dead bodies of Romeo and Juliet,  in the play's most poignant moment, the two griefstricken families agree to end their feud once and for all.

inveterate.sentence: He is an inveterate smoker and has told his family and friends that there is no way he will ever quit.

vacillate.meaning: verb: be undecided about something; waver between conflicting positions or courses of action
vacillate.sentence: Some students vacillate between schools when deciding which to attend, while others focus only on one school.

garrulous.sentence: Lynne was garrulous: once, she had a fifteen minute conversation with a stranger before she realized the woman didn't speak English.

trite.meaning: adjective: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
trite.sentence: Many style guides recommend not using idioms in writing because these trite expressions are uninteresting and show a lack of imagination on the part of the writer.

prodigious.meaning: adjective: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe
prodigious.sentence: After the relatively small homerun totals in the "dead ball" era, Babe Ruth's homerun totals were truly prodigious: every year, he set a new all-time record.

sporadic.meaning: adjective: recurring in scattered and irregular or unpredictable instances
sporadic.sentence: The signals were at first sporadic, but now we detect a clear, consistent pattern of electromagnetic radiation emanating from deep space.

austere.sentence: His lifestyle of revelry and luxurious excess could hardly be called austere.

audacity.meaning: noun: aggressive boldness in social situations
audacity.sentence: Mike was upset at the man who not only cut in front of him at the ticket counter but also had the audacity to cut in front of him at the bathroom line.

pedestrian.sentence: While Nan was always engaged in philosophical speculation, her brother was occupied with far more pedestrian concerns: how to earn a salary and run a household.

intrepid.sentence: Captain Ahab was an intrepid captain whose reckless and fearless style ultimately lead to his downfall.

pernicious.meaning: adjective: exceedingly harmful; working or spreading in a hidden and injurious way
pernicious.sentence: The most successful viruses are pernicious: an infected person may feel perfectly healthy for several months while incubating and spreading the virus.

antithetical.meaning: adjective: sharply contrasted in character or purpose
antithetical.sentence: His deep emotional involvement with these ideas is, in fact, antithetical to the detachment Buddhism preaches.

subversive.meaning: adjective: in opposition to an established system or institution.
subversive.sentence: The ruling political party has begun a campaign to shut down subversive websites that it deems as a threat to "national safety."

reverent.meaning: adjective: feeling or showing profound respect or veneration
reverent.sentence: The professor could speak objectively about the other composers, but he always lectured about Brahms with a particularly reverent air, unable to offer a single criticism of his compositions.

brazen.meaning: adjective: unrestrained by convention or propriety
brazen.sentence: Their large "donations" to the local police department gave the drug cartel the brazen confidence to do their business out in the open.

dilettante.meaning: noun: an amateur who engages in an activity without serious intentions and who pretends to have knowledge
dilettante.sentence: Fred has no formal medical training; while he likes to claim authority on medical issues, he is little more than a dilettante.

munificent.sentence: Uncle Charley was known for his munificence, giving all seven of his nephews lavish Christmas presents each year.

ostracize.meaning: verb: exclude from a community or group
ostracize.sentence: Later in his life, Leo Tolstoy was ostracized from the Russian Orthodox Church for his writings that contradicted church doctrine.

scrupulous.meaning: adjective: characterized by extreme care and great effort
scrupulous.sentence: Because of his scrupulous nature, Mary put him in charge of numbering and cataloging the entire collection of rare stamps.

inscrutable.sentence: His speech was so dense and confusing that many in the audience found it inscrutable.

circumscribe.sentence: Their tour of South America was circumscribed so that they saw only popular destinations and avoided the dangerous parts of cities.

propitious.meaning: adjective: presenting favorable circumstances; likely to result in or show signs of success
propitious.sentence: The child's heartbeat is still weak, but I am seeing many propitious signs and I think that she may be healing.

foment.meaning: verb: try to stir up public opinion
foment.sentence: After having his pay cut, Phil spread vicious rumors about his boss, hoping to foment a general feeling of discontent.

accolade.meaning: noun: an award or praise granted as a special honor
accolade.sentence: Jean Paul-Sartre was not a fan of accolades, and as such, he refused to accept the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1964.

constituent.meaning: noun: a citizen who is represented in a government by officials for whom he or she votes
constituent.sentence: The mayor's constituents are no longer happy with her performance and plan to vote for another candidate in the upcoming election.

prolific.sentence: Schubert was the most prolific composer, producing hundreds of hours of music before he died at the age of 31.

sanction.meaning: verb: give authority or permission to
sanction.sentence: The authorities have sanctioned the use of the wilderness reserve for public use; many expect to see hikers and campers enjoying the park in the coming months.

arcane.meaning: adjective: requiring secret or mysterious knowledge
arcane.sentence: Most college fraternities are known for arcane rituals that those hoping to join the fraternity must learn.

myriad.sentence: There are a myriad of internet sites hawking pills that claim to boost energy for hours on end.

haphazard.meaning: adjective: marked by great carelessness; dependent upon or characterized by chance
haphazard.sentence: Many golf courses are designed with great care, but the greens on the county golf course seem entirely haphazard.

irrevocable.meaning: adjective: incapable of being retracted or revoked
irrevocable.sentence: Once you enter your plea to the court, it is irrevocable so think carefully about what you will say.

rescind.sentence: The man's driver's license was rescinded after his tenth car accident, which meant he would never be allowed to legally drive again.

repudiate.meaning: verb: reject as untrue or unfounded
repudiate.sentence: Many in the public believed the rumors of a UFO crash outside town, so the chief of police did everything he could to repudiate the rumors.

gauche.sentence: Sylvester says the most gauche things, such as telling a girl he liked that she was much prettier when she wore makeup.

sycophant.meaning: noun: a person who tries to please someone in order to gain a personal advantage
sycophant.sentence: The CEO was unaware of the damaging consequences of his choices, largely because he surrounded himself with sycophants who would never dare criticize him.

tempered.sentence: The wide-eyed optimism of her youth was now tempered after she had worked many years in the criminal justice system.

resurgent.meaning: adjective: rising again as to new life and vigor
resurgent.sentence: The team sank to fourth place in June, but is now resurgent and about to win the division.

winsome.meaning: adjective: charming in a childlike or naive way
winsome.sentence: She was winsome by nature, and many people were drawn to this free and playful spirit.

tractable.meaning: adjective: readily reacting to suggestions and influences; easily managed (controlled or taught or molded)
tractable.sentence: Compared to middle school students, who have an untamed wildness about them, high school students are somewhat more tractable.

arbitrary.meaning: adjective: based on a random, groundless decision
arbitrary.sentence: One of the arbitrary decrees in place during the emperor's rule is that all citizens pay him weekly homage at his palace.

taciturn.sentence: While the CEO enthusiastically shares his plans and agenda with all who will listen, the CFO is far more taciturn, rarely revealing his perspective.

nonplussed.meaning: adjective: unsure how to act or respond
nonplussed.sentence: Shirley was totally nonplussed when the angry motorist cut her off and then stuck his finger out the window.

capricious.meaning: adjective: determined by chance or impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
capricious.sentence: Nearly every month our capricious CEO had a new plan to turn the company around, and none of them worked because we never gave them the time they needed to succeed.

maladroit.sentence: As a child she was quite maladroit, but as an adult, she has become an adept dancer.

mendacity.meaning: noun: the tendency to be untruthful
mendacity.sentence: I can forgive her for her mendacity but only because she is a child and is seeing what she can get away with.

transient.meaning: adjective: lasting a very short time
transient.sentence: The unpredictable and transient nature of deja vu makes it a very difficult phenomenon to study properly.

edifying.meaning: adjective: enlightening or uplifting so as to encourage intellectual or moral improvement
edifying.sentence: I recently read an article in the Times about whether good literature is edifying or not; specifically, does reading more make a person more moral.

craven.sentence: Though the man could have at least alerted the police, he crouched cravenly in the corner as the old woman was mugged.

erudite.meaning: adjective: having or showing profound knowledge
erudite.sentence: Before the Internet, the library was typically where you would find erudite readers.

specious.meaning: adjective: based on pretense; deceptively pleasing
specious.sentence: Almost every image on TV is specious and not to be trusted.

arduous.meaning: adjective: demanding considerable mental effort and skill; testing powers of endurance
arduous.sentence: In order to deal with the arduous cross-country journey, truck drivers often survive on a string of caffeinated drinks, staying awake for up to 30 hours at a time.

imprudent.sentence: Hitler, like Napoleon, made the imprudent move of invading Russia in winter, suffering even more casualties than Napoleon had.

jovial.meaning: adjective: full of or showing high-spirited merriment
jovial.sentence: The presidential candidate and her supporters were jovial once it was clear that she had won.

ignominious.meaning: adjective: (used of conduct or character) deserving or bringing disgrace or shame
ignominious.sentence: Since the politician preached ethics and morality, his texting of revealing photographs was ignominious, bringing shame on both himself and his party.

maverick.meaning: noun: someone who exhibits great independence in thought and action
maverick.sentence: Officer Kelly was a maverick, rarely following police protocols or adopting the conventions for speech common among his fellow officers.

opulence.meaning: noun: wealth as evidenced by sumptuous living
opulence.sentence: Russian oligarchs are famous for their opulence, living in fancy homes and dining on expensive caviar.

timorous.meaning: adjective: timid by nature or revealing fear and nervousness
timorous.sentence: Since this was her first time debating on stage and before an audience, Di's voice was timorous and quiet for the first 10 minutes.

anomaly.meaning: noun: something that is not normal, standard, or expected
anomaly.sentence: After finding an anomaly in the data, she knew that she would have to conduct her experiment again.

polemic.meaning: noun: a strong verbal or written attack on someone or something.
polemic.sentence: The professor launched into a polemic, claiming that Freudian theory was a pack of lies that absolutely destroyed European literary theory.

reproach.sentence: At first, Sarah was going to yell at the boy, but she didn't want to reproach him for telling the truth about the situation.

sullen.meaning: adjective: showing a brooding ill humor
sullen.sentence: Herbert took board games too seriously, often appearing sullen after losing.

furtive.meaning: adjective: marked by quiet and caution and secrecy; taking pains to avoid being observed
furtive.sentence: While at work, George and his boss Regina felt the need to be as furtive as possible about their romantic relationship.

rebuke.meaning: verb: criticize severely or angrily; censure
rebuke.sentence: The police chief rebuked the two officers whose irresponsible decisions almost led to the deaths of seven innocent by-standers.

dilatory.sentence: Lawyers use dilatory tactics so that it takes years before the case is actually decided.

stringent.meaning: adjective: demanding strict attention to rules and procedures
stringent.sentence: Most of the students disliked the teacher because of his stringent homework policy, but many students would later thank him for demanding so much from them.

askance.meaning: adverb: with a look of suspicion or disapproval
askance.sentence: The old couple looked askance on the teenagers seated next to them, whispering to each other, "They've got rings through their noses and purple hair!"

elicit.meaning: verb: call forth (emotions, feelings, and responses)
elicit.sentence: Just smiling--even if you are depressed--can elicit feelings of pleasure and happiness.

efficacious.sentence: Since Maggie's cough syrup, which had expired five years back, was no longer efficacious, she coughed through the night.

bolster.sentence: The case for the suspect's innocence was bolstered considerably by the fact that neither fingerprints nor DNA were found at the scene.

mundane.meaning: adjective: repetitive and boring; not spiritual
mundane.sentence: Nancy found doing dishes a thorougly mundane task, although Peter found a kind of Zen pleasure in the chore.

appease.meaning: verb: pacify by acceding to the demands of
appease.sentence: Neville Chamberlain, the British prime minister during WWII, tried to appease Hitler and in doing so sent a clear message: you can walk all over us.

harried.meaning: adjective: troubled persistently especially with petty annoyances
harried.sentence: With a team of new hires to train, Martha was constantly harried with little questions and could not focus on her projects.

disseminate.meaning: verb: cause to become widely known
disseminate.sentence: Before the effects of anesthesia were disseminated, patients had to experience the full pain of a surgery.

Magoosh Score Estimator.meaning: noun: After taking a practice exam, determine your score on the GRE 340-point scale.  Learn more at http://gre.magoosh.com
Magoosh Score Estimator.sentence: Mike scored a 335 on a practice exam using the Magoosh score estimator.

duress.sentence: The witness said he signed the contract under duress and argued that the court should cancel the agreement.

flux.meaning: noun: a state of uncertainty about what should be done (usually following some important event)
flux.sentence: Ever since Elvira resigned as the head of marketing, everything about our sales strategy has been in a state of flux.

contrition.meaning: noun: the feeling of remorse or guilt that comes from doing something bad
contrition.sentence: Those who show contrition during their prison terms--especially when under review by a parole board--often get shortened sentences.

misconstrue.meaning: verb: interpret in the wrong way
misconstrue.sentence: The politician never trusted journalists because he thought that they would misconstrue his words and misrepresent his positions.

posit.sentence: Initially, Einstein posited a repulsive force to balance Gravity, but then rejected that idea as a blunder.

economical.sentence: Journalists favor an economical style of writing, in which no unnecessary words are used and every sentence is as short as possible.

banality.meaning: noun: a trite or obvious remark
banality.sentence: Herbert regarded the minister's remark as a mere banality until Sharon pointed out profound implications to the seemingly obvious words.

indecorous.meaning: adjective: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is right or proper in polite society
indecorous.sentence: Eating with elbows on the table is considered indecorous in refined circles.

nuance.meaning: noun: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude
nuance.sentence: Because of the nuances involved in this case, I hired an outside consultant to advise us and help.

antipathy.meaning: noun: an intense feeling of dislike or aversion
antipathy.sentence: Maria had an antipathy for tour groups, often bolting to the other side of the museum as soon as she saw a chaperone leading a group of wide-eyed tourists.

placate.meaning: verb: cause to be more favorably inclined; gain the good will of
placate.sentence: I was able to placate the angry mob of students by promising to bring cookies on Monday.

deleterious.sentence: The BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was deleterious to the fishing industry in the southern states.

fastidious.meaning: adjective: overly concerned with details; fussy
fastidious.sentence: Whitney is fastidious about her shoes, arranging them on a shelf in a specific order, each pair evenly spaced.

esoteric.meaning: adjective: confined to and understandable by only an enlightened inner circle
esoteric.sentence: Map collecting is an esoteric hobby to most, but to geography geeks it is a highly enjoyable pastime.

dispassionate.meaning: adjective: unaffected by strong emotion or prejudice
dispassionate.sentence: A good scientist should be dispassionate, focusing purely on what the evidence says, without personal attachment.

impartial.meaning: adjective: free from undue bias or preconceived opinions
impartial.sentence: The judge was not impartial since he had been bribed by the witness's family.

pejorative.meaning: adjective: expressing disapproval (usu. refers to a term)
pejorative.sentence: Most psychologists object to the pejorative term "shrink", believing that they expand the human mind, not limit it.

truncate.meaning: verb: reduce the length of something
truncate.sentence: The soccer game was truncated when the monsoon rain began to fall.

meanings.meaning: verb: to examine and remove objectionable material
meanings.sentence: Every fall, high school English teachers are inundated by requests to censor their curriculum by removing The Catcher in the Rye and Scarlet Letter from their reading lists.

meanings.meaning: noun: an official who censors material
meanings.sentence: The censor insisted that every reference to drugs should be removed from the manuscript.

indigenous.meaning: adjective: originating in a certain area
indigenous.sentence: The plants and animals indigenous to Australia are notably different from those indigenous to the U.S—one look at a duckbill platypus and you know you’re not dealing with an opossum.

meanings.meaning: noun: the peak or highest point
meanings.sentence: After hiking for seven days, the climbers finally reached the summit of Mount Kilimanjaro.

meanings.meaning: noun: a meeting of high-level leaders
meanings.sentence: Since climate change policy has been mired in congressional fighting, this summit should help set the goals for president's next term.

diabolical.meaning: adjective: to be extremely wicked like the devil
diabolical.sentence: The conspirators, willing to dispatch anyone who stood in their way, hatched a diabolical plan to take over the city.

profuse.meaning: adjective: plentiful; pouring out in abundance
profuse.sentence:
During mile 20 of the Hawaii Marathon, Dwayne was sweating so profusely that he stopped to take off 
his shirt, and ran the remaining six miles wearing nothing more than skimpy shorts.

thrifty.sentence: He was economical, spending his money thriftily and on items considered essential.

reprobate.meaning: noun: a person without morals who is disapproved of
reprobate.sentence: Mr. Smith’s two boys couldn’t be more different; one was a hard-working and principled, the other was the town reprobate, always having run-ins with the law.

demean.meaning: verb: to insult; to cause someone to lose dignity or respect
demean.sentence: At first the soccer players bantered back and forth, but as soon as one of the players became demeaning, calling the other's mother a water buffalo, the ref whipped out a red card.

hound.sentence: An implacable foe of corruption, Eliot Ness hounded out graft in all forms—he even helped nab Al Capone.

affable.meaning: adjective: likeable; easy to talk to
affable.sentence: For all his surface affability, Marco was remarkably glum when he wasn’t around other people.

meanings.meaning: verb: to trick or swindle
meanings.sentence: Once again a get-rich-fast Internet scheme had duped Harold into submitting a $5,000 check to a sham operation.

meanings.meaning: noun: a person who is easily tricked or swindled
meanings.sentence: The charlatan mistook the crowd for a bunch of dupes, but the crowd was quickly on to him and decried his bald-faced attempt to bilk them.

inundate.sentence: The newsroom was inundated with false reports that only made it more difficult for the newscasters to provide an objective account of the bank robbery.

zenith.sentence: At the zenith of his artistic career, Elvis was outselling any other artist on the charts.

pine.sentence: Standing forlornly by the window, she pined for her lost love.

indignant.meaning: adjective: feeling anger over a perceived injustice
indignant.sentence: When the cyclist swerved into traffic, it forced the driver to brake and elicited an indignant shout of "Hey, punk, watch where you're going!"

embroiled.meaning: verb: involved in argument or contention
embroiled.sentence: These days we are never short of a D.C. politician embroiled in scandal—a welcome phenomenon for those who, having barely finished feasting on the sordid details of one imbroglio, can sink their teeth into a fresh one.

affluent.sentence: The center of the city had sadly become a pit of penury, while, only five miles away, multi-million dollar homes spoke of affluence.

voracious.meaning: adjective: very hungry; approaching an activity with gusto
voracious.sentence: Steven was a voracious reader, sometimes finishing two novels in the same day.

spendthrift.meaning: noun: one who spends money extravagantly
spendthrift.sentence: Taking weekly trips to Vegas, Megan was a spendthrift whose excesses eventually caught up to her.

vindictive.meaning: adjective: to have a very strong desire for revenge
vindictive.sentence: Though the other girl had only lightly poked fun of Vanessa's choice in attire, Vanessa was so vindictive that she waited for an entire semester to get the perfect revenge.

unnerve.meaning: verb: to make nervous or upset
unnerve.sentence: At one time unnerved by math problems, she began avidly “Magoosh-ing”, and soon became adept at even combinations and permutations questions.

peruse.sentence: Instead of perusing important documents, people all too often rush to the bottom of the page and plaster their signatures at the bottom.

thoroughgoing.sentence: As a thoroughgoing bibliophile, one who had turned his house into a veritable library, he shocked his friends when he bought a Kindle.

remiss.meaning: adjective: to be negligent in one’s duty
remiss.sentence: Remiss in his duty to keep the school functioning efficiently, the principal was relieved of his position after only three months.

serendipity.meaning: noun: the instance in which an accidental, fortunate discovery is made
serendipity.sentence: By pure serendipity, Sarah discovered, at a flea market in Peoria, a matching earring to replace the one that fell down the storm drain back home.

telltale.sentence: The many telltale signs of chronic smoking include yellow teeth, and a persistent, hacking cough.

variance.meaning: noun: the quality of being different
variance.sentence: The cynic quipped, “There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to lie”.

acme.meaning: noun: the highest point of achievement
acme.sentence: The new Cessna airplanes will be the acme of comfort, offering reclining seats and ample legroom.

dog.meaning: verb: to pursue relentlessly; to hound
dog.sentence: Throughout his life, he was dogged by insecurities that inhibited personal growth.

tender.sentence: The government was loath to tender more money in the fear that it might set off inflation.

screed.sentence: Joey had difficulty hanging out with his former best friend Perry, who, during his entire cup of coffee, enumerated all of the government’s deficiencies--only to break ranks and launch into some screed against big business.

miser.meaning: noun: a person who doesn't like to spend money (because they are greedy)
miser.sentence: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.

err.sentence: He erred in thinking that "indigent" and "indignant" were synonyms.

inflammatory.sentence: It only takes one person to leave an inflammatory comment on an Internet thread for that thread to blow up into pages upon pages of reader indignation.

mesmerize.sentence: The plot and the characters were so well developed that many viewers were mesmerized, unable to move their eyes from the screen for even a single second.

underwrite.sentence: The latest symphony broadcast was made possible with underwriting from the Carnegie Endowment.

bleak.meaning: adjective: having a depressing or gloomy outlook
bleak.sentence: Unremitting overcast skies tend to lead people to create bleak literature and lugubrious music — compare England’s band Radiohead to any band from Southern California.

telling.meaning: adjective: significant and revealing of another factor
telling.sentence: Her unbecoming dress was very telling when it came to her sense of fashion.

tirade.sentence: In terms of political change, a tirade oftentimes does little more than make the person speaking red in the face.

pinnacle.sentence: At its pinnacle, the Roman Empire extended across most of the landmass of Eurasia, a feat not paralleled to the rise of the British Empire in the 18th and 19th century.

macabre.meaning: adjective: suggesting the horror of death and decay; gruesome
macabre.sentence: Edgar Allen Poe was considered the master of the macabre; his stories vividly describe the moment leading up to—and often those moments after—a grisly death.

erratic.sentence: It came as no surprise to pundits that the President’s attempt at re-election floundered; even during his term, support for his policies was erratic, with an approval rating jumping anywhere from 30 to 60 percent.

indict.meaning: verb: to formally charge or accuse of wrong-doing
indict.sentence: The bankrobber was indicted on several major charges, including possession of a firearm.

demure.meaning: adjective: to be modest and shy
demure.sentence: The portrait of her in a simple white blouse was sweet and demure.

slapdash.meaning: adjective: carelessly and hastily put together
slapdash.sentence: The office building had been constructed in a slapdash manner, so it did not surprise officials when, during a small earthquake, a large crack emerged on the façade of the building.

candid.sentence: Even with a perfect stranger, Charles was always candid and would rarely hold anything back.

amiable.sentence: Amy’s name was very apt: she was so amiable that she was twice voted class president.

stipend.sentence: He was hoping for a monthly allowance loan from the government, but after no such stipend was forthcoming he realized he would have to seek other means of paying for his college tuition.

retiring.meaning: adjective: to be shy, and to be inclined to retract from company
retiring.sentence: Nelson was always the first to leave soirees—rather than mill about with “fashionable” folk, he was retiring, and preferred the solitude of his garret.

insolvent.meaning: adjective: unable to pay one's bills; bankrupt
insolvent.sentence: With credit card bills skyrocketing, a shockingly large number of Americans are truly insolvent.

sanctimonious.meaning: adjective: making a show of being pious; holier-than-thou
sanctimonious.sentence: Even during the quiet sanctity of evening prayer, she held her chin high, a sanctimonious sneer forming on her face as she eyed those who were attending church for the first time.

paucity.sentence: There is a paucity of jobs hiring today that require menial skills, since most such jobs have either been automated or outsourced.

extenuating.meaning: adjective: making less guilty or more forgivable
extenuating.sentence: The jury was hardly moved by the man’s plea that his loneliness was an extenuating factor in his crime of dognapping a prized pooch.

pugnacious.meaning: adjective: eager to fight or argue; verbally combative
pugnacious.sentence: The comedian told one flat joke after another, and when the audience started booing, he pugnaciously spat back at them, “Hey, you think this is easy – why don’t you buffoons give it a shot?”

cadaverous.sentence: Some actors take challenging roles in which they have to lose so much weight that they appear cadaverous.

becoming.sentence: Her dress was becoming and made her look even more beautiful.

flush.sentence: The exam's passage is flush with difficult words, words that you may have learned only yesterday.

misanthrope.sentence: Kevin is such a misanthrope that he refused to attend the Christmas party, claiming that everyone's happiness was "fake" and "annoying."

moment.sentence: Despite the initial hullabaloo, the play was of no great moment in Hampton’s writing career, and within a few years the public quickly forgot his foray into theater arts.

beatific.sentence: Often we imagine all monks to wear the beatific smile of the Buddha, but, like any of us, a monk can have a bad day and not look very happy.

raft.meaning: noun: a large number of something
raft.sentence: Despite a raft of city ordinances passed by an overzealous council, noise pollution continued unabated in the megalopolis.

animosity.sentence: The governor’s animosity toward his rival was only inflamed when the latter spread false lies regarding the governor’s first term.

chauvinist.meaning: noun: a person who believes in the superiority of their group
chauvinist.sentence: The chauvinist lives on both sides of the political spectrum, outright shunning anybody whose ideas are not consistent with his own.

cogent.sentence: A cogent argument will change the minds of even the most skeptical audience.

contrite.sentence: Though he stole his little sister’s licorice stick with malevolent glee, Chucky soon became contrite when his sister wouldn't stop crying.

melee.meaning: noun: a wild, confusing fight or struggle
melee.sentence: After enduring daily taunts about my name, I became enraged and pummeled the schoolyard bully and his sycophantic friends in a brutal melee.

errant.meaning: adjective: to be wandering; not sticking to a circumscribed path
errant.sentence: Unlike his peers, who spent their hours studying in the library, Matthew preferred errant walks through the university campus.

immaterial.sentence: The judge found the defendant’s comments immaterial to the trial, and summarily dismissed him from the witness stand.

catalyst.meaning: noun: something that speeds up an event
catalyst.sentence: Rosa Parks's refusal to give up her bus seat acted as a catalyst for the Civil Rights Movement, setting into motion historic changes for African-Americans.

badger.sentence: Badgered by his parents to find a job, the 30-year-old loafer instead joined a gang of itinerant musicians.

desecrate.meaning: verb: to willfully violate or destroy a sacred place
desecrate.sentence: After desecrating the pharaoh's tomb, the archaeologist soon fell victim to a horrible illness.

lassitude.meaning: noun: extreme tiredness, either mental or physical
lassitude.sentence: Upon finishing a 6-hour standardized exam, Dahlia emerged from the testing center overcome by lassitude.

hodgepodge.meaning: noun: a confusing mixture or jumble
hodgepodge.sentence: Those in attendance represented a hodgepodge of the city's denizens: chimney sweepers could be seen sitting elbow to elbow with stockbrokers.

exhort.meaning: verb: to strongly urge on; encourage
exhort.sentence: Nelson’s parents exhorted him to study medicine, urging him to choose a respectable profession; intransigent, Nelson left home to become a graffiti artist.

replete.meaning: adjective: completely stocked or furnished with something
replete.sentence: Only weeks after the hurricane made landfall, the local supermarket shelves were replete with goods, so quick was the disaster relief response.

scintillating.meaning: adjective: describes someone who is brilliant and lively
scintillating.sentence: Richard Feynman was renowned for his scintillating lectures—the arcana of quantum physics was made lucid as he wrote animatedly on the chalkboard.

start.meaning: verb: to suddenly move in a particular direction
start.sentence: All alone in the mansion, Henrietta started when she heard a sound.

disparate.meaning: adjective: two things are fundamentally different
disparate.sentence: With the advent of machines capable of looking inside the brain, fields as disparate as religion and biology have been brought together by scientists trying to understand what happens in the brain when people have a religious experience.

fleece.sentence: Many people have been fleeced by Internet scams and never received their money back.

stem.meaning: verb: to hold back or limit the flow or growth of something
stem.sentence: To stem the tide of applications, the prestigious Ivy requires that each applicant score at least 330 on the Revised GRE.

heyday.meaning: noun: the pinnacle or top of a time period or career
heyday.sentence: During the heyday of Prohibition, bootlegging had become such a lucrative business that many who had been opposed to the 18th Amendment began to fear it would be repealed.

sanguine.sentence: With the prospect of having to learn 3,000 words during the course of the summer, Paul was anything but sanguine.

ferret.meaning: verb: to search for something persistently
ferret.sentence: Ever the resourceful lexicographer, Fenton was able to ferret out the word origin of highly obscure words.

avarice.meaning: noun: greed (one of the seven deadly sins)
avarice.sentence: The Spanish conquistadors were known for their avarice, plundering Incan land and stealing Incan gold.

junta.meaning: noun: an aggressive takeover by a group (usually military); the group that executes such a takeover
junta.sentence: As dangerous of a threat as North Korea is, some analysts believe that were a junta suddenly to gain power, it could be even more unpredictable and bellicose than the current leadership

apex.sentence: The Ivy League is considered the apex of the higher education system.

vicarious.meaning: adjective: felt or undergone as if one were taking part in the experience or feelings of another
vicarious.sentence: The advent of twitter is a celebrity stalker's dream, as he or she can—through hundreds of intimate "tweets"—vicariously live the life of a famous person.

imponderable.meaning: adjective: impossible to estimate or figure out
imponderable.sentence: According to many lawmakers, the huge variety of factors affecting society make devising an efficient healthcare system an imponderable task.

aboveboard.sentence:
The mayor, despite his avuncular face plastered about the city, was hardly aboveboard – some concluded that it was his ingratiating smile that allowed him to engage in corrupt behavior and get
away with it.

wax.meaning: verb: to gradually increase in size or intensity
wax.sentence: Her enthusiasm for the diva’s new album only waxed with each song; by the end of the album, it was her favorite CD yet.

meanings.meaning: verb: to limit (usually modifying the growth of something)
meanings.sentence: Deserted for six months, the property began to look more like a jungle and less like a residence—weeds grew unchecked in the front yard

meanings.meaning: noun: the condition of being held back or limited
meanings.sentence: When government abuses are not kept in check, that government is likely to become autocratic.

amok.meaning: adverb: in a frenzied or uncontrolled state
amok.sentence: Wherever the bowl haircut teen-idol went, his legions of screaming fans ran through the streets amok, hoping for a glance at his boyish face.

virago.meaning: noun: an ill-tempered or violent woman
virago.sentence: Poor Billy was the victim of the virago’s invective—she railed at him for a good 30-minutes about how he is the scum of the earth for speaking loudly on his cellphone in public.

checkered.meaning: adjective: marked by disreputable or unfortunate happenings
checkered.sentence: One by one, the presidential candidates dropped out of the race, their respective checkered pasts— from embezzlement to infidelity—sabotaging their campaigns.

corroborate.meaning: verb: to confirm or lend support to (usually an idea or claim)
corroborate.sentence: Her claim that frog populations were falling precipitously in Central America was corroborated by locals, who reported that many species of frogs had seemingly vanished overnight.

preemptive.meaning: adjective: done before someone else can do it
preemptive.sentence: Just as Martha was about to take the only cookie left on the table, Noah preemptively swiped it.

cardinal.sentence: Most cultures consider gambling a cardinal sin and thus have outlawed its practice.

unconscionable.sentence: The lawyer’s demands were so unconscionable that rather than pay an exorbitant sum or submit himself to any other inconveniences, the defendant decided to find a new lawyer.

moot.meaning: adjective: open to argument or debate; undecidable in a meaningless or irrelevant way
moot.sentence: Since the Board just terminated Steve as the CEO, what the finance committee might have thought of his proposed marketing plan for next year is now a moot point.

plodding.sentence: Charlie may seem to run at a plodding pace, but he is an ultramarathoner, meaning he runs distances of up to 100 miles, and can run for ten hours at a stretch.

dearth.sentence: I am surprised by the dearth of fast food chains; this is America and I assumed they were on every street.

meanings.meaning: adjective: having or revealing supreme mastery or skill
meanings.sentence: Tyler was the consummate musician: he was able to play the guitar, harmonica, and the drum at the same time.

meanings.meaning: verb: to make perfect and complete in every respect
meanings.sentence: The restoration of the ancient church was only consummated after a twenty years of labor.

patronize.sentence: She says she genuinely wanted to help me, but instead she patronized me, constantly pointing out how I was inferior to her.

flounder.sentence: Sylvia has excelled at advanced calculus, but ironically, when she has to deal with taxes, she flounders.

autonomously.meaning: adverb: Acting independently; self-governing (of a country)
autonomously.sentence: Many of the factory workers are worried about being replaced by machines and computers that will work completely autonomously.

jocular.meaning: adjective: characterized by jokes and good humor
jocular.sentence: My uncle was always in a jocular mood at family gatherings, messing up people's hair and telling knock-knock jokes to anyone who would listen.

malady.sentence: The town was struck by a malady throughout the winter that left most people sick in bed for two weeks.

disheartened.meaning: adjective: made less hopeful or enthusiastic
disheartened.sentence: After the visiting team scored nine times, the home team's fans were disheartened, some leaving the game early.

fledgling.meaning:
adjective: young and inexperienced 
noun: any new participant in some activity
fledgling.sentence: Murray has years of experience in family practice, but he is just a fledgling in surgery.

transitory.meaning: adjective: lasting a very short time
transitory.sentence: If we lived forever and life was not transitory, do you think we would appreciate life less or more?

morose.meaning: adjective: ill-tempered and not inclined to talk; gloomy
morose.sentence: After Stanley found out he was no longer able to go on vacation with his friends, he sat in his room morosely.

muted.sentence: Helen preferred muted earth colors, such as green and brown, to the bright pinks and red her sister liked.

robust.meaning: adjective: sturdy and strong in form, constitution, or construction
robust.sentence: Chris preferred bland and mild beers, but Bhavin preferred a beer with more robust flavor.

resolve.meaning: verb: reach a conclusion after a discussion or deliberation
resolve.sentence: After much thought, Ted resolved not to travel abroad this summer because he didn't have much money in his bank account.

archaic.meaning: adjective: so old as to appear to belong to a different period
archaic.sentence: Hoping to sound intelligent, Mary spoke in archaic English that was right out of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice--needless to say, she didn't have many friends.

impermeable.meaning: adjective: does not allow fluids to pass through
impermeable.sentence: The sand bags placed on the river formed an impermeable barrier, protecting the town from flooding.

quandary.meaning: noun: state of uncertainty or perplexity especially as requiring a choice between equally unfavorable options
quandary.sentence: Steve certainly is in a quandary: if he doesn't call Elaine, she will blame him for everything, but if he does call her, the evidence of where he currently is could cost him his job.

snide.meaning: adjective: expressive of contempt; derogatory or mocking in an indirect way
snide.sentence: The chairman interpreted Taylor's question about promotions as a snide remark, but in all innocence Taylor was trying to figure out the company's process.

meander.sentence: A casual observer might have thought that Peter was meandering through the city, but that day he was actually seeking out those places where he and his long lost love had once visited.

ascendancy.meaning: noun: the state that exists when one person or group has power over another
ascendancy.sentence: The ascendancy of the Carlsbad water polo team is clear—they have a decade of championships behind them.

apprehension.sentence: Test day can be one of pure apprehension, as many students worry about their test scores.

avid.meaning: adjective: marked by active interest and enthusiasm
avid.sentence: Martin is an avid birdwatcher, often taking long hikes into remote mountains to see some rare eagle.

thwart.meaning: verb: hinder or prevent (the efforts, plans, or desires) of
thwart.sentence: I wanted to spend a week in New York this autumn, but the high costs of travel and lodging thwarted my plans.

endemic.meaning: adjective: native; originating where it is found
endemic.sentence: Irish cuisine makes great use of potatoes, but ironically, the potato is not endemic to Ireland.

meanings.meaning: verb: speak, plead, or argue in favor of
meanings.sentence: While the senator privately approved of gay marriage, he was unwilling to advocate for the cause in a public venue.

meanings.meaning: noun: a person who pleads for a cause or propounds an idea
meanings.sentence: Martin Luther King Jr. was a tireless advocate for the rights of African-Americans in the United States.

ingenuity.meaning: noun: the power of creative imagination
ingenuity.sentence: Daedalus was famous for his ingenuity; he was able to fashion his son Icarus with a pair of wings, using wax to hold them together.

ornate.meaning: adjective: marked by elaborate rhetoric and elaborated with decorative details
ornate.sentence: The ornate Victorian and Edwardian homes spread throughout San Francisco are my favorite part of the city.

meanings.meaning: adjective: (of weather) unpleasant, stormy
meanings.sentence: After a week of inclement weather, we finally are able to go outside and enjoy the sun.

meanings.meaning: adjective: used of persons or behavior; showing no mercy
meanings.sentence: Marcus Aurelius, though a fair man, was inclement to Christians during his reign, persecuting them violently.

pithy.meaning: adjective: concise and full of meaning
pithy.sentence: I enjoy reading the Daodejing for its pithy and insightful prose; it always gives me something to think about.

meanings.meaning: adjective: capable of being shaped or bent or drawn out
meanings.sentence: The clay became malleable and easy to work with after a little water was added.

meanings.meaning: adjective: easily influenced
meanings.sentence: My little brother is so malleable that I can convince him to sneak cookies from the cupboard for me.

degrade.meaning: verb: reduce in worth or character, usually verbally
degrade.sentence: Jesse had mockingly pointed out all of Nancy's faults in front of their friends, publicly degrading the poor girl.

meanings.meaning: noun: a desirable state
meanings.sentence: Modern technology has been a boon to the travel industry.

meanings.meaning: adjective: very close and convivial
meanings.sentence: He was a boon companion to many, and will be sadly missed.

elusive.meaning: adjective: difficult to capture or difficult to remember
elusive.sentence: Many first time skydivers say that describing the act of falling from the sky is elusive.

stolid.meaning: adjective: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility; not easily aroused or excited
stolid.sentence: Elephants may appear stolid to casual observers, but they actually have passionate emotional lives.

renege.meaning: verb: fail to fulfill a promise or obligation
renege.sentence: We will no longer work with that vendor since it has reneged on nearly every agreement.

incessant.meaning: adjective: uninterrupted in time and indefinitely long continuing
incessant.sentence: I don't mind small children in brief doses, but I think the incessant exposure that their parents have to them would quickly wear me down.

discriminate.meaning: verb: recognize or perceive the difference
discriminate.sentence: Sarah couldn't discriminate between a good wine and a bad wine, so she avoided wine tastings.

meanings.meaning: verb: turn away from by persuasion
meanings.sentence: His mother tried to deter him from joining the army, but he was too intoxicated with the idea of war to listen.

meanings.meaning: verb: try to prevent; show opposition to
meanings.sentence: The government's primary job should involve deterring paths to war, not finding ways to start them.

disenfranchise.sentence: The U.S. Constitution disenfranchised women until 1920 when they were given the right to vote.

guffaw.sentence: Whenever the jester fell to the ground in mock pain, the king guffawed, exposing his yellow, fang-like teeth.

respite.meaning: noun: a pause from doing something (as work)
respite.sentence: Every afternoon, the small company has a respite in which workers play foosball or board games.

fete.sentence: After World War II, war heroes were feted at first but quickly forgotten.

proponent.meaning: noun: a person who pleads for a cause or propounds an idea
proponent.sentence: Ironically, the leading proponent of Flat-Earth Theory flies all over the world in an effort to win more adherents.

raffish.meaning: adjective: marked by a carefree unconventionality or disreputableness
raffish.sentence: The men found him raffish, but the women adored his smart clothes and casual attitude.

entice.meaning: verb: get someone to do something through (often false or exaggerated) promises
entice.sentence: Harold enticed his wife, Maude, to go on a vacation to Hawaii, with promises of luaus on the beach and all-you-can-eat seafood buffets.

obdurate.meaning: adjective: unable to be persuaded or moved emotionally; stubborn; unyielding.
obdurate.sentence: No number of pleas and bribes would get him to change his obdurate attitude.

appreciable.meaning: adjective: large enough to be noticed (usu. refers to an amount)
appreciable.sentence: There is an appreciable difference between those who say they can get the job done and those who actually get the job done.

impede.meaning: verb: be a hindrance or obstacle to
impede.sentence: Since the police sergeant had to train the pair of new hires, progress in his own case was impeded.

tumult.meaning: noun: a state of chaos, noise and confusion
tumult.sentence: Riots broke out just in front of our apartment building, and the tumult continued late into the night.

cornucopia.meaning: noun: an abundant supply of something good
cornucopia.sentence: The International Food Expo was a cornucopia of culinary delights: gourmet foods from every continent were under one roof.

meanings.meaning: adjective: marked by complexity and richness of detail
meanings.sentence: Thomas, on returning from Morocco, replaced his dirty gray carpet with an elaborate one he'd brought back with him.

meanings.meaning: verb: explain in more detail
meanings.sentence: Most high school physics teachers find themselves elaborating the same point over and over again, since many concepts confuse students.

urbane.meaning: adjective: showing a high degree of refinement and the assurance that comes from wide social experience
urbane.sentence: Because of his service as an intelligence officer and his refined tastes, W. Somerset Maugham became the inspiration for the urbane and sophisticate spy James Bond.

augment.sentence: Ideally, the restaurant's augmented menu will expand its clientele and increase its profits.

martial.meaning: adjective: suggesting war or military life
martial.sentence: Americans tend to remember Abraham Lincoln as kindly and wise, not at all martial, despite the fact that he was involved in the fiercest war America has even fought.

buck.sentence: The profits at our firm bucked the general downturn that affected the real estate industry.

euphoria.meaning: noun: a feeling of great (usually exaggerated) elation
euphoria.sentence: The euphoria of winning her first gold medal in the 100 meter dash overwhelmed Shelly-Ann Fraser and she wept tears of immense joy.

conducive.meaning: adjective: making a situation or outcome more likely to happen
conducive.sentence: Studying in a quiet room is conducive to learning; studying in a noisy environment makes learning more difficult.

debase.meaning: verb: reduce the quality or value of something
debase.sentence: The third-rate script so debased the film that not even the flawless acting could save it from being a flop.

derisive.meaning: adjective: abusing vocally; expressing contempt or ridicule
derisive.sentence: I was surprised by her derisive tone; usually, she is sweet, soft spoken, and congenial.

genteel.meaning: adjective: marked by refinement in taste and manners
genteel.sentence: A live string quartet would provide a more genteel air to the wedding than would a folk singer.

glib.meaning: adjective: (of a person) speaking with ease but without sincerity
glib.sentence: I have found that the more glib the salesman, the worse the product.

lucid.meaning: adjective: (of language) transparently clear; easily understandable
lucid.sentence: Though Walters writes about physics and time travel, his writing is always lucid, so readers with little scientific training can understand difficult concepts.

spurn.sentence: She spurned all his flattery and proposals, and so he walked off embarrassed and sad.

commendable.sentence: The efforts of the firefighters running into the burning building were commendable.

unruly.meaning: adjective: (of persons) noisy and lacking in restraint or discipline; unwilling to submit to authority
unruly.sentence: Walk in to any preschool and I am sure that you will find an unruly and chaotic scene—unless it's nap time.

illicit.meaning: adjective: contrary to or forbidden by law
illicit.sentence: Though Al Capone was engaged in many illicit activities, he was finally arrested for income tax evasion, a relatively minor offense.

credence.sentence: He placed no credence in psychics, claiming that they offered no special powers beyond the ability to make people part with their money.

empathetic.meaning: adjective: showing understanding and ready comprehension of other peoples' states and emotions
empathetic.sentence: Most discrimination and hatred is based on a lack of empathetic awareness of people that have the same aspirations and fears.

sentimental.meaning: adjective: effusively or insincerely emotional, especially in art, music, and literature
sentimental.sentence: I don't like romanticism for the same reason I don't like melodramatic acting and soap operas—overly sentimental.

grovel.sentence: Every time Susan comes to the office, Frank grovels as if she were about to fire him.

vacuous.meaning: adjective: devoid of intelligence, matter, or significance
vacuous.sentence: To the journalist's pointed question, the senator gave a vacuous response, mixing a few of his overall campaign slogans with platitudes and completely avoiding the controversial subject of the question.

uncompromising.sentence: The relationship between Bart and Hilda ultimately failed because they were both so uncompromising, never wanting to change their opinions.

pertinent.meaning: adjective: having precise or logical relevance to the matter at hand
pertinent.sentence: While the salaries of the players might draw attention in the media, such monetary figures are not pertinent to the question of who plays the best on the field.

altruism.meaning: noun: the quality of unselfish concern for the welfare of others
altruism.sentence: Albert Schweitzer spent most of his life doing missionary work as a doctor in Africa, seeking no reward, apparently motivated only by altruism.

smattering.meaning: noun: a slight or superficial understanding of a subject; a small amount of something
smattering.sentence: I know only a smattering of German, but Helen is able to read German newspapers and converse with natives.

irresolute.meaning: adjective: uncertain how to act or proceed
irresolute.sentence: He stood irresolute at the split in the trail, not sure which route would lead back to the camp.

impeccable.sentence: He was impeccably dressed in the latest fashion without a single crease or stain.

perpetuate.sentence: If you do not let him do things for himself, you are merely perpetuating bad habits that will be even harder to break in the future.

detrimental.meaning: adjective: (sometimes followed by "to") causing harm or injury
detrimental.sentence: Many know that smoking is detrimental to your health, but processed sugar in large quantities is equally bad.

meanings.meaning: adjective: kind
meanings.sentence: I remember my grandfather's face was wrinkled, benign, and calm.

meanings.meaning: adjective: (medicine) not dangerous to health; not recurrent or progressive
meanings.sentence: The tumor located in your ear lobe seems to be benign and should not cause you any trouble.

egotist.meaning: noun: a conceited and self-centered person
egotist.sentence: An egotist, Natasha had few friends because of her inability to talk about anything except her dream of becoming the next American Idol.

whimsical.meaning: adjective: determined by impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
whimsical.sentence: Adults look to kids and envy their whimsical nature at times, wishing that they could act without reason and play without limitation.

fickle.meaning: adjective: liable to sudden unpredictable change, esp. in affections or attachments
fickle.sentence: She was so fickle in her politics, it was hard to pinpoint her beliefs; one week she would embrace a side, and the next week she would denounce it.

perennial.meaning: adjective: lasting an indefinitely long time; eternal; everlasting
perennial.sentence: Even at the old-timers games, Stan Musial would get the loudest cheer: he was a perennial favorite of the fans there.

assail.meaning: verb: attack in speech or writing
assail.sentence: In the weekly paper, the editor assailed the governor for wasting hundreds of thousands of dollars in public projects that quickly failed.

facetious.sentence: Facetious behavior will not be tolerated during sex education class; it's time for all of you to treat these matters like mature adults.

rankle.meaning: verb: gnaw into; make resentful or angry
rankle.sentence: His constant whistling would rankle her, sometimes causing her to leave in a huff.

hamstrung.sentence: The FBI has made so many restrictions on the local police that they are absolutely hamstrung, unable to accomplish anything.

surly.meaning: adjective: inclined to anger or bad feelings with overtones of menace
surly.sentence: Every morning, Bhavin was a surly, unhappy person, but once he ate breakfast, he became loving, laughing, and a joy to be around.

tawdry.meaning: adjective: tastelessly showy; cheap and shoddy
tawdry.sentence: Carol expected to find New York City magical, the way so many movies had portrayed it, but she was surprised how often tawdry displays took the place of genuine elegance.

meanings.meaning: adjective: Unspoiled, untouched (usu. of nature)
meanings.sentence: The glacial lake was pristine and we filled our canteens to drink deeply.

meanings.meaning: adjective: Immaculately clean and unused
meanings.sentence: Drill sergeants are known for demanding pristine cabinets, uniforms, and beds, and often make new recruits clean and clean and clean until they meet the expected high standards.

genial.sentence: Betty is a genial young woman: everyone she meets is put at ease by her elegance and grace.

precedent.meaning: noun: an example that is used to justify similar occurrences at a later time
precedent.sentence: The principal explained that even though one student had done modelling work outside of school, the outfits that student wore in those photographs in no way established a precedent for what could be worn at school dances.

contemptuous.meaning: adjective: scornful, looking down at others with a sneering attitude
contemptuous.sentence: Always on the forefront of fashion, Vanessa looked contemptuously at anyone wearing dated clothing.

inadvertent.meaning: adjective: happening by chance or unexpectedly or unintentionally
inadvertent.sentence: Although Prohibition was rooted in noble ideals, the inadvertent and costly consequences of making alcohol illegal in the U.S. led to its repeal.

banish.meaning: verb: expel from a community, residence, or location; drive away
banish.sentence: The most difficult part of the fast was banishing thoughts of food.

assuage.meaning: verb: make something intense less severe
assuage.sentence: Her fear that the new college would be filled with unknown faces was assuaged when she recognized her childhood friend standing in line.
